title: Policy Applications (Restricted Distribution)
text:
My research develops quantitative tools that can support economic intelligence and policy analysis in environments characterized by strategic interaction, uncertainty, and systemic interdependence.


I study how production networks transmit shocks arising from trade restrictions, sanctions, and input shortages. The models identify critical nodes and substitution margins that determine whether disruptions are absorbed through reallocation or amplified into persistent vulnerabilities. This framework can inform assessments of supply-chain robustness and exposure to foreign dependencies.



My work on energy substitution and capital adjustment characterizes how economies respond over time to energy price shocks, carbon pricing, and technology constraints. These dynamics are directly relevant for evaluating energy dependence, transition risks, and the strategic implications of supply disruptions.



By embedding policy frictions in dynamic general equilibrium models, I examine how small, persistent distortions generate nonlinear aggregate responses. The approach is suited to identifying early-stage vulnerabilities that may not be apparent in reduced-form or sector-level analyses.



Across projects, I focus on how policy instruments interact with private investment incentives. This perspective is relevant for evaluating the unintended consequences of industrial policy, sanctions, and regulatory interventions in adversarial or competitive environments.
This work is intended to complement qualitative intelligence assessments with formal, mechanism-based economic analysis.

title: Tadhg Taylor-McGreal
text:
Tadhg Taylor-McGreal
MAEP Economics, McMaster University
I am studying how policy-imposed frictions and external shocks propagate through interconnected production systems. My work focuses on identifying when trade restrictions, energy disruptions, and industrial policy interventions induce adaptive reallocation, and when they instead generate persistent vulnerabilities and systemic risk.
Using dynamic AGE models, I study how investment incentives, substitution elasticities, and network structure shape aggregate resilience. My research is motivated by questions central to economic security, including supply-chain robustness, energy dependence, and exposure to geopolitical shocks.
My work is intended to support forward-looking risk assessment in environments characterized by strategic interaction, uncertainty, and incomplete information.
Research interests:
Macroeconomics · Production Networks · Energy Policy · Industrial Policy · Economic Security

title: Strategic Frictions and Systemic Risk
text: Policy frictions are rarely isolated. In tightly coupled economies, small distortions can propagate through production networks, magnify uncertainty, and alter the strategic calculus of states and firms. My interest is in identifying which nodes and linkages act as accelerants, and where targeted intervention can dampen systemic risk without imposing persistent misallocation.

title: Research
text:
I develop and solve static and dynamic general equilibrium models to study how policy constraints and external shocks affect investment, production, and reallocation in networked economies. My work emphasizes identifying structural conditions under which localized disruptions propagate into economy-wide vulnerabilities.
These tools are applied to questions in energy and climate policy, trade and industrial policy, and economic security, with a focus on mechanisms relevant for early-warning analysis and resilience assessment.

Working Papers

Optimal Carbon Taxation in a Dynamic General Equilibrium Economy
Tadhg Taylor-McGreal
I develop and solve a dynamic general equilibrium model with capital accumulation and heterogeneous energy technologies to characterize the welfare-maximizing carbon tax path. The model highlights how investment responses and energy substitution jointly shape optimal policy and transition dynamics.

title: Research
text:
Work in Process

Policy Constraints, Production Networks, and Endogenous Investment
This project studies how trade restrictions, policy uncertainty, and input constraints propagate through production networks and alter firms’ incentives to invest in capacity, sourcing flexibility, and technology adoption. I characterize when constraints induce adaptive reorganization versus persistent fragility, with implications for supply-chain security, energy dependence, and exposure to geopolitical shocks.
The framework is designed to identify leverage points and bottlenecks that are not visible in partial-equilibrium or sector-isolated analyses.



Neural Networks in Strategic Environments
I developed a convolutional neural network to study the limits of pure function approximation in high-dimensional strategic settings. Using chess as a controlled environment, the model maps raw board states to position evaluations without search, rollout, or lookahead.
The project examines when pattern recognition succeeds in adversarial environments and when it fails due to strategic nonlocality, path dependence, and regime shifts. Results highlight systematic failure modes of static predictors when incentives, constraints, or opponent responses change—providing insight into the limits of reduced-form prediction in strategic economic and policy contexts.
